The style is conversational, but the mathematics is rigorous.

title: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers
text:
2.1 🔹 Boundedness
Lila:
“Acharya, we already have natural numbers, integers, rationals. Why do we need real numbers? Aren’t rationals enough?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“That is a wise question, Lila. Let us test the rationals. Can you think of a number whose square is 2?”
Lila:
“Well… if I try,
- \(1.4^2 = 1.96\),
- \(1.41^2 = 1.9881\),
- \(1.414^2 = 1.999396\)…
We get closer, but never exactly 2.”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“So, do you think there is a rational number \(q\) with \(q^2 = 2\)?”
Lila:
“No. I’ve seen the proof that \(\sqrt{2}\) is irrational.”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Correct. But notice this: even if \(\sqrt{2}\) is not rational, we can approximate it as closely as we like using rationals — \(1.4, 1.41, 1.414\ldots\) The rationals are dense: between any two rationals there is another. Yet something is still missing.”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Let us capture this rigorously. Consider the set
\[
S = \{ x \in \mathbb{Q} : x^2 < 2 \}.
\]
Is there a number that is always greater than every element of this set?”
Lila:
“Sure, 2 is bigger than all of them. So is 1.5, or 1.42.”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Exactly. We call such numbers upper bounds. Here is a precise definition.”
Similarly, we can define a lower bound.
Lila:
“Acharya, you defined what it means for a number to be an upper or lower bound. But what about the set itself? When do we call a set bounded?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“A good question, Lila. Here is the precise definition.”
crumbs: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers

title: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers
text:
Definition (Upper bound).
A number \(M\) is an upper bound of a set \(S \subseteq \mathbb{R}\) if \[
x \leq M \quad \text{for all } x \in S.
\]



Definition (Lower bound).
A number \(m\) is a lower bound of a set \(S \subseteq \mathbb{R}\) if \[
x \geq m \quad \text{for all } x \in S.
\]





Definition (Bounded Set).
A set \(S \subseteq \mathbb{R}\) is said to be bounded above if it has an upper bound.
It is bounded below if it has a lower bound.
If \(S\) is both bounded above and below, then \(S\) is called a bounded set.
Formally, there exist real numbers \(m, M \in \mathbb{R}\) such that \[
m \le x \le M \quad \text{for all } x \in S.
\]
crumbs: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers

title: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers
text:
2.2 🔹 Examples

Example 1.
The interval \([0,1]\) is bounded above by \(1, 2, \ldots\) and bounded below by \(0, -1, \ldots\).
In fact, \(0\) and \(1\) are the tightest bounds, so the set is bounded.


Example 2.
The set \(\mathbb{N} = \{1,2,3,\ldots\}\) is bounded below (by \(1, 0, -5, \ldots\)),
but it is not bounded above — it grows without end.


Example 3.
The set \(\mathbb{Z}\) of all integers has no upper bound and no lower bound.
Thus, it is not bounded.

Lila:
“So a set is bounded if it fits within some finite interval \([m,M]\) on the number line?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Exactly! That’s the intuition — bounded sets live inside some finite cage on the real line.
Unbounded sets escape that cage, either upward, downward, or both.”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“But among upper bounds some are tighter than others. Which number feels like the ‘tightest’ upper bound for our set
\[
S = \{ x \in \mathbb{Q} : x^2 < 2 \}?
\]”
Lila:
“It should be \(\sqrt{2}\), since that’s where the set stops.”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Indeed. But here is the problem: \(\sqrt{2}\) is not in \(\mathbb{Q}\). So the rationals cannot capture the least upper bound of this set.”
crumbs: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers

title: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers
text:
2.3 🔹 Supremum
Acharya Bhaskara:
“This brings us to another definition:”

Definition (Least Upper Bound / Supremum).
Let \(A\) be a nonempty subset of \(\mathbb{R}\).
If \(A\) is bounded above, then a number \(M\) is said to be the supremum (least upper bound) of \(A\) if:

\(x \le M\) for all \(x \in A\), and

for any \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists \(x \in A\) such that \(x > M - \varepsilon\).



Definition (Greatest Lower Bound / Infimum).
Let \(A\) be a nonempty subset of \(\mathbb{R}\).
If \(A\) is bounded below, then a number \(m\) is said to be the infimum (greatest lower bound) of \(A\) if:

\(m \le x\) for all \(x \in A\), and

for any \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists \(x \in A\) such that \(x < m + \varepsilon\).


Lila:
“So the problem with rationals is that some sets don’t have a supremum inside them?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Precisely. The rationals are dense but not complete. The missing piece is the completeness property of the real numbers.”
crumbs: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers

title: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers
text:
2.4 🔹 Completeness Axiom
Acharya Bhaskara:
“The defining property of the real numbers is this:

Completeness Axiom: Every nonempty set of real numbers that is bounded above has a least upper bound (supremum) in \(\mathbb{R}\).

This axiom is what makes the real line whole.”

Lila:
“So for \(S = \{ x : x^2 < 2 \}\), the supremum is \(\sqrt{2}\), which does exist in \(\mathbb{R}\).”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Exactly. And that, Lila, is the difference between rationals and reals. Completeness fills the gaps and makes the real line continuous. Without it, calculus itself would crumble.”
crumbs: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers

title: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers
text:
2.5 ✅ Try it yourself

(Optional) Give an example of a subset of \(\mathbb{Q}\) that is bounded above in \(\mathbb{Q}\) but has no least upper bound in \(\mathbb{Q}\).
crumbs: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers

title: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers
text:
2.6 Proofs
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Dear Lila, it is not enough that we make statements about numbers. We need to prove them too!”
Lila:
“But Acharya, why do we need to prove them? If something feels obviously true, can’t we just accept it?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Ah, that is the difference between intuition and mathematics. Intuition is helpful, but it can also mislead us. Proofs are what give mathematics its certainty. Without proof, we have only belief. With proof, we have knowledge.”
Lila:
“Can you give me an example?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Certainly. Take the statement: ‘The square root of 2 is irrational.’ Long ago, many believed that every number was a fraction. But through proof, we know with certainty that \(\sqrt{2}\) cannot be expressed as \(\tfrac{p}{q}\) with integers \(p\) and \(q\).”
Lila:
“I see — so proofs are like the backbone that holds mathematics upright.”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Exactly! Proofs force us to use definitions carefully and follow logical steps. They protect us from hidden assumptions. And, more importantly, they reveal why a statement is true, not just that it is true.”
Lila:
“So every time we state something in real analysis — like that every bounded set has a supremum — we must also prove it?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Indeed. That completeness axiom we discussed is itself an assumption. But once accepted, we must prove all consequences from it rigorously. That is the art of analysis: building a tower of truth, brick by brick, proof by proof.”
crumbs: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers

title: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers
section: 2.7 Worked Example: Supremum and Infimum of \((0,1)\)
text:
2.7 Worked Example: Supremum and Infimum of \((0,1)\)
Lila:
“Acharya, can we apply these definitions right away? Let’s take the open interval \(S = (0,1)\). What are \(\sup S\) and \(\inf S\)?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Excellent! Let’s prove that \(\sup S = 1\) and \(\inf S = 0\).”

Proof. Proof.
Let \(S = (0,1)\).

Supremum.

Upper bound: For every \(x \in S\), we have \(x < 1\), so \(1\) is an upper bound.

Leastness: Suppose \(M < 1\). Then choose
\[
x = \tfrac{M+1}{2}.
\] Clearly \(0 < x < 1\), so \(x \in S\), but \(x > M\).
Thus \(M\) is not an upper bound.
Hence, \(\sup S = 1\).

Infimum.

Lower bound: For every \(x \in S\), we have \(x > 0\), so \(0\) is a lower bound.

Greatestness: Suppose \(m > 0\). Then choose
\[
x = \tfrac{m}{2}.
\] Since \(0 < x < m\), we have \(x \in S\) but \(x < m\).
Thus \(m\) is not a lower bound.
Hence, \(\inf S = 0\).




Lila:
“So the trick was to show that \(1\) works as an upper bound, but anything smaller fails.”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Exactly, Lila. That is the essence of supremum proofs: two steps — upper bound, and leastness. Once you master this structure, many proofs in analysis will follow the same pattern.”
Lila:
“So even though neither \(0\) nor \(1\) are in the set \((0,1)\), they still serve as its infimum and supremum?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Exactly! That’s one of the key ideas in real analysis: bounds need not belong to the set itself. Supremum and infimum live in the real line, not necessarily inside the set.”
crumbs: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers

title: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers
text:
2.8 🔹 Density
Lila:
“Acharya, earlier you said the rationals are dense. What exactly does that mean?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Good question, Lila. Let me give you the formal definition.”

Definition (Density).
A subset \(D \subseteq \mathbb{R}\) is said to be dense in \(\mathbb{R}\) if
for every pair of real numbers \(a,b\) with \(a < b\), there exists \(x \in D\) such that \[
a < x < b.
\]

Lila:
“So, no matter how small the interval, there’s always a rational inside it?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Exactly! The rationals \(\mathbb{Q}\) are dense in \(\mathbb{R}\).
In contrast, the integers \(\mathbb{Z}\) are not dense, because between two consecutive integers, like \(2\) and \(3\), no integer lies strictly in between.” ## 🔹 Example: Rationals are Dense
Lila:
“Acharya, can we prove that the rationals are really dense in \(\mathbb{R}\)?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Of course. This is a fundamental fact: between any two real numbers, there lies a rational.”


Proof. Proof.
Let \(a,b \in \mathbb{R}\) with \(a < b\).
We need to show there exists a rational \(q \in \mathbb{Q}\) such that \(a < q < b\).
Since \(b-a > 0\), by the Archimedean Property there exists a natural number \(n\) such that \[
\frac{1}{n} < b - a.
\]
Now consider the integers \(k\) satisfying \[
k > a n.
\] Let \(k\) be the smallest such integer.
Then \[
k-1 \le a n < k.
\] Dividing by \(n\) gives \[
\frac{k-1}{n} \le a < \frac{k}{n}.
\]
So \(\tfrac{k}{n}\) is a rational number greater than \(a\).
Moreover, since \(\tfrac{1}{n} < b-a\), we have \[
\frac{k}{n} < a + \frac{1}{n} < b.
\]
Thus \[
a < \frac{k}{n} < b,
\] and \(\frac{k}{n} \in \mathbb{Q}\) lies strictly between \(a\) and \(b\).
Therefore, \(\mathbb{Q}\) is dense in \(\mathbb{R}\).


Lila:
“So we used the Archimedean Property to trap a rational in between \(a\) and \(b\)!”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Exactly. This proof not only shows that rationals are dense, it also highlights how the structure of the real numbers — via the Archimedean Property — guarantees their richness.”
crumbs: 2  Level 1: Completeness of the Real Numbers

title: 3  Level 2: Intervals and Their Characterization
text:
3.1 🔹 What Are Intervals?
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Lila, now that we understand completeness, let us move to another fundamental idea in real analysis — intervals.”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“An interval is simply a stretch of the real line without gaps. Formally:
All of these are examples of intervals.”
Lila:
“So intervals are just stretches of the real line. Isn’t that obvious?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“It looks obvious, yes, but let us be precise. What makes these sets intervals and not just any arbitrary subset of \(\mathbb{R}\)? The essence is that they have no gaps. This brings us to an important theorem.”
crumbs: 3  Level 2: Intervals and Their Characterization

title: 3  Level 2: Intervals and Their Characterization
text:
A set of the form \([a,b] = \{x \in \mathbb{R} : a \le x \le b\}\) is a closed interval.

\((a,b) = \{x \in \mathbb{R} : a < x < b\}\) is an open interval.

Similarly, we have half-open intervals \((a,b], [a,b)\).

And we allow intervals to extend infinitely: \((-\infty,a), [a,\infty), (-\infty,\infty) = \mathbb{R}\).







3.1.1 🔹 Characterization Theorem

Characterization Theorem of Intervals.
A nonempty subset \(S \subseteq \mathbb{R}\) is an interval if and only if it has the following property:

Whenever \(x,y \in S\) with \(x < y\), then every real number \(z\) with \(x < z < y\) also belongs to \(S\).

Equivalently, if \(x,y \in S\) and \(x < y\), then the entire closed segment \([x,y]\) is contained in \(S\).



3.1.1.1 🔹 Examples

Example 1.
Take \(S = (0,1)\). If \(x,y \in S\) and \(x < y\), then any \(z\) with \(x < z < y\) also satisfies \(0 < z < 1\), so \(z \in S\).
Thus \((0,1)\) is an interval.


Example 2.
Take \(S = (0,1) \cup (2,3)\). Here \(0.5 \in S\) and \(2.5 \in S\), but the point \(1.5\) between them is not in \(S\).
So \(S\) fails the characterization property and is not an interval.


Lila:
“So the theorem says: intervals are exactly those sets that never leave out the points in between.”
crumbs: 3  Level 2: Intervals and Their Characterization

title: 3  Level 2: Intervals and Their Characterization
text:
3.2 🔹 A Subtle Example: Working in \(\mathbb{Q}\)
Lila:
“Acharya, what about the set
\[
S = \{x \in \mathbb{Q} : x^2 < 2\}?
\]
Is that an interval?”
Acharya Bhaskara:
“An excellent question! Let us analyze carefully.”


Remark (Intervals in \(\mathbb{Q}\) vs \(\mathbb{R}\)).

In \(\mathbb{Q}\):
\[
S = \{x \in \mathbb{Q} : x^2 < 2\}
\] contains all rationals with \(x^2 < 2\), e.g. \(1.41 \in S\), but excludes any rational \(y\) with \(y^2 > 2\), such as \(1.42\).
Crucially, it also excludes \(\sqrt{2}\), because \(\sqrt{2} \notin \mathbb{Q}\).
So \(S\) “stops” at \(\sqrt{2}\) but never includes it. This breaks the interval property inside \(\mathbb{Q}\).
In \(\mathbb{R}\):
The same description becomes
\[
\{x \in \mathbb{R} : x^2 < 2\} = (-\sqrt{2}, \sqrt{2}),
\]
which is an interval, because the reals contain the missing boundary points.

👉 This shows the difference between density (rationals are everywhere between rationals) and completeness (the reals include all limit points, like \(\sqrt{2}\)).



3.2.0.1 ✅ Try it yourself

Exercise. Decide whether the following sets are intervals:

\([0,1)\cup(1,2]\)

\((-\infty,0)\cup(0,\infty)\)
\(\mathbb{Z}\) (the set of all integers)




Show Answers


\([0,1)\cup(1,2]\) → ❌ Not an interval. The point \(1\) is missing, so the set has a gap.
\((-\infty,0)\cup(0,\infty)\) → ❌ Not an interval. \(0\) is missing.
\(\mathbb{Z}\) → ❌ Not an interval. There are infinitely many gaps (e.g., between \(2\) and \(3\) there is no integer).





3.2.1 🔹 The Nested Interval Property
Acharya Bhaskara:
“Lila, now that you understand what intervals are, let me show you one of their most remarkable features — the Nested Interval Property. It is a direct consequence of completeness.”


Nested Interval Property.
Let \((I_n)\) be a sequence of closed intervals \[
I_n = [a_n, b_n], \quad n=1,2,3,\ldots
\] such that

The intervals are nested:
\[
I_1 \supseteq I_2 \supseteq I_3 \supseteq \cdots
\]
The lengths shrink to \(0\):
\[
\lim_{n \to \infty} (b_n - a_n) = 0.
\]

Then there exists a unique point \(c \in \mathbb{R}\) such that \[
\bigcap_{n=1}^\infty I_n = \{c\}.
\]




3.2.2 🔹 Example

Example.
Take \[
I_n = \left[0, \tfrac{1}{n}\right].
\] Clearly \(I_1 \supseteq I_2 \supseteq I_3 \supseteq \cdots\), and the lengths \(b_n - a_n = \tfrac{1}{n} \to 0\).
Thus \[
\bigcap_{n=1}^\infty I_n = \{0\}.
\]




3.2.3 ✅ Try it Yourself

Exercise.
Consider the nested intervals \[
I_n = \left[1, 1 + \tfrac{1}{n}\right].
\]

Are the intervals nested?

What is \(\bigcap_{n=1}^\infty I_n\)?




Show Answers

Yes, the intervals are nested since each \(I_{n+1} \subseteq I_n\).
The lengths \(b_n - a_n = \tfrac{1}{n} \to 0\).
Hence, \[
\bigcap_{n=1}^\infty I_n = \{1\}.
\]
crumbs: 3  Level 2: Intervals and Their Characterization

title: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]
text:
4.1 Binary representation
Lila: Acharya, what about the decimal representation of real numbers? We still don’t know exactly how it is constructed.
Acharya Bhaskar: A very good question, Lila! To understand decimal representations properly, it is helpful to first look at the binary representation of numbers.
Lila: Ah! I know that computers use binary numbers to represent data. But I’m curious—how can real numbers be expressed in binary? And does this have any connection with the Nested Interval Property?
Acharya Bhaskar: Excellent thought, Lila. Indeed, binary representation arises quite naturally if we repeatedly bisect the interval \([0,1]\). Let’s explore how this works.
Step 1: First division Take any real number \(x \in [0,1]\). Divide \([0,1]\) into two halves: \[
[0,\tfrac{1}{2}] \quad \text{and} \quad [\tfrac{1}{2}, 1].
\]
So the first binary digit \(a_1\) tells us whether \(x\) lies in the left or right half.
Step 2: Second division Now, take the half chosen in Step 1 and bisect it again.
Depending on which subinterval contains \(x\), we assign \(a_2=0\) (left) or \(a_2=1\) (right).
Lila: So \(a_2\) refines the position of \(x\) within the chosen half?
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. Continuing this process, at the \(n\)-th step we decide whether \(x\) lies in the left or right subinterval, and record the digit \(a_n\).
Step 3: Infinite process Thus we build a sequence of digits \(a_1,a_2,a_3,\dots\) where each \(a_i \in \{0,1\}\). These digits define the binary expansion: \[
x = 0.a_1a_2a_3\ldots \quad \text{(in base 2)}.
\]
Formally, \[
x = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{a_n}{2^n}.
\]
Lila: Ah, so each digit corresponds to a left-or-right choice in successive subdivisions of \([0,1]\). That’s just like building a nested sequence of intervals!
Acharya Bhaskar: Well observed. In fact, the intersection of these nested intervals is exactly the single point \(x\). The binary expansion records the entire path of choices.
crumbs: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]

title: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]
crumbs: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]

title: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]
text:
4.2 Example
Take \(x=\tfrac{5}{8}\).
- First step: \(x\in [\tfrac{1}{2},1]\), so \(a_1=1\).
- Second step: \(x\in [\tfrac{1}{2},\tfrac{3}{4}]\), so \(a_2=0\).
- Third step: \(x\in [\tfrac{5}{8},\tfrac{3}{4}]\), so \(a_3=1\).
Thus, \[
x = 0.101_2 = \tfrac{1}{2} + 0 + \tfrac{1}{8} = \tfrac{5}{8}.
\]

Lila: That’s beautiful! Binary digits are nothing but a record of the successive bisections that trap the number.
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly, and this construction shows how every \(x \in [0,1]\) can be encoded as an infinite binary string. It connects the geometry of intervals with the arithmetic of expansions.
crumbs: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]

title: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]
text:
4.3 Decimal Representation via [0,1]
Lila: Acharya, now that I understand binary representation, what about decimal representation of real numbers? How do we obtain that?
Acharya Bhaskar: Very good question, Lila. The idea is very similar to binary, except instead of dividing into two parts, we divide the interval \([0,1]\) into ten equal parts.

First digit
Acharya Bhaskar: Let \(x \in [0,1]\). We divide \([0,1]\) into ten subintervals: \[
\Big[0,\tfrac{1}{10}\Big], \Big[\tfrac{1}{10},\tfrac{2}{10}\Big], \dots, \Big[\tfrac{9}{10},1\Big].
\]

If \(x\) lies in the first interval, set \(d_1=0\).

If \(x\) lies in the second interval, set \(d_1=1\).

And so on, up to \(d_1=9\) if \(x \in [\tfrac{9}{10},1]\).

This \(d_1\) is the first decimal digit after the point.
Lila: So \(d_1\) tells us in which tenth of the interval \([0,1]\) the number \(x\) lies.

Second digit
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. Now, take the subinterval chosen in Step 1 and divide it again into ten equal parts.
The position of \(x\) in this subdivision gives us \(d_2\), the second decimal digit.
Lila: Just like in binary, but with ten instead of two!

Infinite process
Acharya Bhaskar: Yes. Continuing this process, we construct digits \(d_1,d_2,d_3,\dots\) with \(d_i \in \{0,1,2,\dots,9\}\).
These digits define the decimal expansion: \[
x = 0.d_1d_2d_3\ldots \quad \text{(in base 10)}.
\]
Formally, \[
x = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{d_n}{10^n}.
\]


4.3.1 Example: Find the decimal repersentation of \(x = \tfrac{2}{7}\)

First step: \(2/7\) lies in the third subinterval \([2/10,3/10]\), so \(d_1=2\).

Second step: within \([2/10,3/10]\), divide into tenths: \([28/100,29/100]\) contains \(2/7\), so \(d_2=8\).

Third step: now inside \([28/100,29/100]\), we find \(2/7\) in \([285/1000,286/1000]\), so \(d_3=5\).

Fourth step: inside \([285/1000,286/1000]\), we find \(2/7\) in \([2857/10000,2858/10000]\), so \(d_4=7\).

Continuing this way, we uncover the repeating decimal expansion: \[
\frac{2}{7} = 0.285714285714\ldots
\]
Lila: That’s neat! The digits appear directly from locating \(x\) in finer and finer tenths.



4.3.2 A subtlety: non-uniqueness
Lila: Are decimal representations always unique?
Acharya Bhaskar: A very sharp question, Lila. In fact, they are not always unique. For example, \[
0.5000\ldots = 0.4999\ldots
\] represent the same number.
Lila: Oh, I see. So sometimes a terminating decimal has an alternative representation with repeating \(9\)s.
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. This happens whenever the decimal expansion ends. You may think of it as the final subinterval having two possible “addresses” — one ending in an infinite string of zeros, and the other in an infinite string of nines.
Lila: So aside from this special case, decimal representations are unique?
Acharya Bhaskar: Yes, apart from this subtlety, each real number in \([0,1]\) corresponds to exactly one infinite decimal expansion.

Lila: That clears it up! Decimal representation is really just like binary, except we use partitions into ten instead of two, with a small quirk about repeating \(9\)s.
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly, Lila. And this connection between interval subdivisions and digit expansions is a powerful idea in real analysis.
crumbs: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]

title: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]
section: 5.1 A canonical choice of decimal expansion
text:
5.1 A canonical choice of decimal expansion
Acharya Bhaskar: First a technical but important point. Some numbers admit two decimal expansions, for example \[
0.5000\ldots = 0.4999\ldots.
\] To avoid ambiguity we fix a canonical rule: whenever a number has two decimal expansions, we choose the one that terminates (the expansion ending in infinitely many zeros). Equivalently, we do not use expansions that end with an infinite tail of \(9\)’s.
With this rule, every \(x\in[0,1]\) has a unique decimal expansion \[
x = 0.d_1 d_2 d_3\ldots\qquad (d_i\in\{0,1,\dots,9\}).
\]

text:
5.2 Assume a listing
Acharya Bhaskar: Suppose, for contradiction, that \([0,1]\) is countable. Then there is a list \[
x_1,\; x_2,\; x_3,\; \dots
\] and, by our canonical rule, write each \(x_n\) as \[\begin{align*}
x_1 &= 0.d_{11} d_{12} d_{13}\ldots d_{1n} \ldots,\\
x_2 &= 0.d_{21} d_{22} d_{23}\ldots d_{2n} \ldots,\\
x_3 &= 0.d_{31} d_{32} d_{33}\ldots d_{3n} \ldots,\\
&\vdots \\
x_n &= 0.d_{n1} d_{n2} d_{n3}\ldots d_{nn} \ldots
\end{align*}\]
where \(d_{nk}\in\{0,\dots,9\}\) is the \(k\)-th decimal digit of the \(n\)-th number.
crumbs: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]

title: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]
text:
5.3 The diagonal construction
Acharya Bhaskar: Now build a new decimal sequence \((y_k)\) by changing the \(k\)-th digit of the \(k\)-th listed number. For each \(k\) define \[
y_k :=
\begin{cases}
d_{kk}+1 &\text{if } d_{kk}\in\{0,1,\dots,8\},\\[4pt]
0 &\text{if } d_{kk}=9.
\end{cases}
\] Thus \(y_k\in\{0,\dots,9\}\) and, crucially, \(y_k\neq d_{kk}\) for every \(k\).
Let \[
y := 0.y_1 y_2 y_3 \ldots .
\]
crumbs: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]

title: 4  Level 3: Binary and Decimal Representation via [0,1]
text:
5.4 Why this is a contradiction
Lila: How do we know \(y\) is not on the list?
Acharya Bhaskar: For each \(n\), the \(n\)-th digit of \(y\) equals \(y_n\), which by construction differs from \(d_{nn}\), the \(n\)-th digit of \(x_n\). Therefore \(y\neq x_n\) for every \(n\). In other words, \(y\) is a point of \([0,1]\) not appearing in the supposed complete list. This contradicts the assumption that \([0,1]\) was countable.
Hence \([0,1]\), and therefore \(\mathbb{R}\), is uncountable. ∎

title: 5  Level 4: Sequences and Series
text:
5.1 Introduction
Lila: Acharya, until now we have been exploring real numbers, their representations, and Cantor’s ideas. But what comes next in our journey?
Acharya Bhaskar: A natural next step, Lila, is to study not just individual numbers, but patterns of numbers — how they progress, how they accumulate. This leads us to the study of sequences and series.
crumbs: 5  Level 4: Sequences and Series

title: 5  Level 4: Sequences and Series
text:
5.2 What is a sequence?
Lila: What exactly is a sequence?
Acharya Bhaskar: A sequence is simply an ordered list of numbers: \[
(a_n)_{n=1}^\infty = a_1, a_2, a_3, \dots
\] Each \(a_n\) is called the \(n\)-th term. The idea is that as \(n\) increases, we can watch how the terms behave — whether they approach a limit, oscillate, or grow without bound.
Lila: So a sequence is like watching numbers march along, step by step?
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly! For example: - \(a_n = \tfrac{1}{n}\) gives the sequence \(1, \tfrac{1}{2}, \tfrac{1}{3}, \dots\) which gets closer and closer to \(0\).
- \(a_n = (-1)^n\) gives \(-1, 1, -1, 1, \dots\) which jumps back and forth and never settles.
crumbs: 5  Level 4: Sequences and Series

title: 5  Level 4: Sequences and Series
text:
5.3 What is a series?
Lila: And what about a series?
Acharya Bhaskar: A series is what we get when we add up the terms of a sequence: \[
S = \sum_{n=1}^\infty a_n = a_1 + a_2 + a_3 + \cdots
\]
Lila: So if a sequence is footsteps, then a series is like adding the total distance covered?
Acharya Bhaskar: Well said! For example: - The series \(\sum_{n=1}^\infty \tfrac{1}{2^n} = \tfrac{1}{2} + \tfrac{1}{4} + \tfrac{1}{8} + \cdots\) converges to \(1\).
- But the series \(\sum_{n=1}^\infty \tfrac{1}{n} = 1 + \tfrac{1}{2} + \tfrac{1}{3} + \cdots\) grows without bound — it diverges.
crumbs: 5  Level 4: Sequences and Series

title: 5  Level 4: Sequences and Series
text:
5.4 Why study sequences and series?
Lila: Why are these so important?
Acharya Bhaskar: Because they are the language of approximation and analysis: 1. Important numbers like \(e\) and \(\pi\) appear as limits of sequences or sums of series.
2. Functions like \(\sin x\), \(\cos x\), and \(e^x\) can be expressed as infinite series — that’s how we calculate them on computers!
3. Understanding limits of sequences helps us define continuity, derivatives, and integrals.
Lila: So sequences and series are the foundation stones for the rest of calculus and analysis.
Acharya Bhaskar: Precisely. Real analysis begins here, with the careful study of how infinite processes behave.

Acharya Bhaskar (teaser):
“Think of a sequence as footsteps marching towards a destination.
If the footsteps wander endlessly, the sequence diverges.
If they march steadily towards a point, the sequence converges.
And when you add the footsteps together, you create the story of a series.”
## Limits of Sequences
Lila: Acharya, you said some sequences “converge” and some “diverge.” What exactly does it mean for a sequence to converge?
Acharya Bhaskar: Good question, Lila. Intuitively, a sequence converges if its terms get closer and closer to some fixed number, which we call the limit.
Lila: So for \(a_n = \tfrac{1}{n}\), the terms \(1, \tfrac{1}{2}, \tfrac{1}{3}, \dots\) get closer and closer to \(0\), so the limit should be \(0\)?
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. We write \[
\lim_{n\to\infty} \frac{1}{n} = 0.
\]


5.4.1 The formal definition
Acharya Bhaskar: But in real analysis we need precision. So here is the definition:
A sequence \((a_n)\) is said to converge to a number \(L\) if for every \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists a natural number \(K(\varepsilon)\) such that whenever \(n \geq K(\varepsilon)\), we have \[
|a_n - L| < \varepsilon.
\]
Lila: Let me see if I understand. This means: no matter how small an error margin \(\varepsilon\) I choose, if I go far enough in the sequence (beyond some \(K\) that depends on the given \(\varepsilon\)), all terms stay within that margin around \(L\).
Acharya Bhaskar: Well said. That is the precise meaning of convergence.

Example: \(a_n = \tfrac{1}{n}\)
Lila: Could we test this definition with \(a_n = \tfrac{1}{n}\) and \(L=0\)?
Acharya Bhaskar: Certainly.
We want: for every \(\varepsilon>0\), find \(K(\varepsilon)\) such that if \(n\ge K(\varepsilon)\), then \(|\tfrac{1}{n} - 0| < \varepsilon\).
But \(|\tfrac{1}{n} - 0| = \tfrac{1}{n}\).
So we require \(\tfrac{1}{n} < \varepsilon\).
This is the same as \(n > \tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\).
So if we choose \(K(\varepsilon) = \lceil \tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\rceil\), then for all \(n\ge K(\varepsilon)\), the condition is satisfied.
Lila: That works! So the formal definition confirms that \(\tfrac{1}{n} \to 0\).

Example: \(a_n = (-1)^n\)
Lila: And what about \(a_n = (-1)^n\)?
Acharya Bhaskar: Then the terms alternate \(-1, 1, -1, 1, \dots\). Do they get closer to a single value?
Lila: No — they keep jumping back and forth. So this sequence does not converge.
Acharya Bhaskar: Correct. It diverges, because there is no single \(L\) that the terms approach.



5.4.2 Why limits matter
Lila: So convergence is about sequences approaching a fixed target. But why is this so important?
Acharya Bhaskar: Because the notion of limit is the cornerstone of analysis. Continuity, derivatives, integrals, and infinite series all depend on it. Mastering limits of sequences is the first step toward the deeper structures of calculus.
Limit of a function via sequences






NoteConnecting sequence limits and function limits





Lila: Acharya, I understand the limit of a sequence. But what could the limit of sequences have to do with the notion of limits of functions?
Acharya Bhaskar: An excellent question, Lila. In fact, the two ideas are deeply connected.
We say \[
\lim_{x\to a} f(x) = L
\] if and only if for every sequence \((x_n)\) with \(x_n \to a\) and \(x_n \neq a\), the sequence \((f(x_n))\) converges to \(L\).

Lila: So if all possible sequences approaching \(a\) give the same limiting value \(L\) for \(f(x_n)\), then that must be the limit of the function?
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. This is called the sequential criterion for functional limits.
It tells us: instead of thinking about all the infinitely many “ways” of approaching \(a\), it is enough to test every possible sequence converging to \(a\).

Lila: Ah! So the concept of a function limit is really an extension of the idea of sequence limits.
Acharya Bhaskar: Precisely, Lila. That is why we first built a strong foundation with sequences — they are the key to understanding limits of functions.





5.4.3 Another Example of Convergence
Lila: We proved earlier that \(\lim \tfrac{1}{n} = 0\). Could you show me another example, maybe a slightly different sequence?
Acharya Bhaskar: Certainly! Let’s consider the sequence
\[x_n = \frac{1}{n^2+1}.\] I claim that \(\lim_{n \to \infty} x_n = 0\).
Lila: Oh, it looks similar to \(\tfrac{1}{n}\), but the denominator grows even faster. So it should also go to zero, right?
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. Let’s do a rigorous \(\varepsilon\)–\(N\) proof.


Click to see the proof

We want to show that for every \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists \(N \in \mathbb{N}\) such that for all \(n > N\),
\[\Bigg|\frac{1}{n^2+1} - 0\Bigg| < \varepsilon.\]
But
\[\Bigg|\frac{1}{n^2+1}\Bigg| = \frac{1}{n^2+1}.\]
Notice that
\[\frac{1}{n^2+1} < \frac{1}{n^2}.\]
So it is enough to require
\[\frac{1}{n^2} < \varepsilon.\]
This means
\[n^2 > \frac{1}{\varepsilon}, \quad \text{or equivalently} \quad n > \frac{1}{\sqrt{\varepsilon}}.\]
Thus, if we choose
\[N = \left\lceil \frac{1}{\sqrt{\varepsilon}} \right\rceil,\]
then for all \(n > N\),
\[\frac{1}{n^2+1} < \varepsilon.\]
Hence,
\[\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{1}{n^2+1} = 0.\]

Lila: That was neat! So the idea is the same as before, but we had to be careful with the square root this time.
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. You’ll see that many convergence proofs follow a similar structure. The challenge is usually in rearranging inequalities smartly.



5.4.4 A Non–Zero Limit Example
Lila: So far, the examples we’ve done all go to zero. Can you show me a sequence that converges to something other than zero?
Acharya Bhaskar: Of course. Let’s look at
\[x_n = \frac{n}{n+1}.\]
I claim that
\[\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n}{n+1} = 1.\]
Lila: Hmm… when \(n\) is large, \(n+1\) is almost the same as \(n\), so \(\tfrac{n}{n+1}\) should be almost \(1\).
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. Now let’s prove it formally.


Click to see the proof

We want to show: for every \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists \(N \in \mathbb{N}\) such that for all \(n > N\),
\[\Bigg|\frac{n}{n+1} - 1\Bigg| < \varepsilon.\]
Simplify the difference:
\[\Bigg|\frac{n}{n+1} - 1\Bigg| = \Bigg|\frac{n - (n+1)}{n+1}\Bigg| = \frac{1}{n+1}.\]
So we need
\[\frac{1}{n+1} < \varepsilon.\]
That is,
\[n+1 > \frac{1}{\varepsilon} \quad \implies \quad n > \frac{1}{\varepsilon} - 1.\]
Thus, if we choose
\[N = \left\lceil \frac{1}{\varepsilon} - 1 \right\rceil,\]
then for all \(n > N\),
\[\Bigg|\frac{n}{n+1} - 1\Bigg| < \varepsilon.\]
Therefore,
\[\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n}{n+1} = 1.\]

Lila: That was nice! The sequence actually climbs closer and closer to \(1\), never quite reaching it, but the proof shows it really does converge there.
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. This illustrates an important point — limits don’t always have to be zero; the same method works for any real number.


5.4.5 Convergence to a Rational Number
Lila: We’ve seen limits going to \(0\) and \(1\). Can a sequence converge to some other fraction, like \(\tfrac{2}{5}\)?
Acharya Bhaskar: Absolutely! Let’s take
\[x_n = \frac{2n+3}{5n+1}.\]
I claim that
\[\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2n+3}{5n+1} = \frac{2}{5}.\]
Lila: I can guess why — the higher powers of \(n\) dominate, so it’s like \(\tfrac{2n}{5n} = \tfrac{2}{5}\) when \(n\) is large.
Acharya Bhaskar: That’s the intuition. Let’s now prove it rigorously.


Click to see the proof

We want to show: for every \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists \(N \in \mathbb{N}\) such that for all \(n > N\),
\[\Bigg|\frac{2n+3}{5n+1} - \frac{2}{5}\Bigg| < \varepsilon.\]
Simplify the difference:
\[
\frac{2n+3}{5n+1} - \frac{2}{5}
= \frac{5(2n+3) - 2(5n+1)}{5(5n+1)}
= \frac{10n+15 - 10n - 2}{25n+5}
= \frac{13}{25n+5}.
\]
So
\[\Bigg|\frac{2n+3}{5n+1} - \frac{2}{5}\Bigg| = \frac{13}{25n+5}.\]
Now, we want
\[\frac{13}{25n+5} < \varepsilon.\]
This inequality is equivalent to
\[25n+5 > \frac{13}{\varepsilon} \quad \implies \quad n > \frac{13}{25\varepsilon} - \frac{1}{5}.\]
So we can choose
\[N = \left\lceil \frac{13}{25\varepsilon} - \frac{1}{5} \right\rceil.\]
Then for all \(n > N\), we have
\[\Bigg|\frac{2n+3}{5n+1} - \frac{2}{5}\Bigg| < \varepsilon.\]
Therefore,
\[\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2n+3}{5n+1} = \frac{2}{5}.\]

Lila: I see! The algebra looks a bit longer, but the same method works. The main trick was simplifying the difference.
Acharya Bhaskar: Precisely. Once you bring it into a simple form, the \(\varepsilon\)–\(N\) argument falls into place. This shows that sequences can converge to any real number, not just \(0\) or \(1\).


5.4.6 An Example of Divergence
Lila: All the examples so far show sequences settling to a finite number. But what about a sequence that doesn’t converge?
Acharya Bhaskar: Excellent question. Consider the sequence
\[x_n = n.\]
Lila: That just grows bigger and bigger! So it can’t converge to a real number, right?
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. Formally, we say it diverges to infinity. Let’s make this precise.


Click to see the explanation

To say that \(\lim_{n \to \infty} x_n = +\infty\) means:
For every real number \(M > 0\), there exists \(N \in \mathbb{N}\) such that for all \(n > N\),
\[x_n > M.\]
Now, since \(x_n = n\), if you give me any \(M > 0\), I can simply choose
\[N = \lceil M \rceil.\]
Then for all \(n > N\), clearly \(n > M\), so \(x_n > M\).
Thus, the sequence \(\{n\}\) does not converge to a finite limit, but instead diverges to infinity.

Lila: So divergence isn’t just “no limit at all.” Sometimes it means the sequence goes off to infinity in a systematic way.
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. There are also examples where sequences oscillate and fail to have any limit at all — those are divergent in a different sense.


5.4.7 An Oscillating Divergent Sequence
Lila: You said some sequences can diverge by oscillating. Can you show me an example?
Acharya Bhaskar: Certainly. Consider the sequence
\[x_n = (-1)^n.\]
Lila: Oh, so it goes like \(-1, +1, -1, +1, \dots\) That never settles down to a single number.
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. Let’s explain why it does not converge.


Click to see the explanation

Suppose, for contradiction, that \(\lim_{n \to \infty} (-1)^n = L\) for some real number \(L\).
Then by the definition of convergence, for every \(\varepsilon > 0\) there should be an \(N\) such that for all \(n > N\),
\[|(-1)^n - L| < \varepsilon.\]
But notice:
- If \(n\) is even, \((-1)^n = 1\).
- If \(n\) is odd, \((-1)^n = -1\).
So the sequence keeps jumping between \(1\) and \(-1\), no matter how large \(n\) becomes.
For example, if we take \(\varepsilon = \tfrac{1}{2}\), then the condition requires all terms \((-1)^n\) to lie within an interval of radius \(\tfrac{1}{2}\) around \(L\).
But one subsequence is constantly \(1\), and the other is constantly \(-1\). These two points are \(2\) units apart, which is much larger than \(\tfrac{1}{2}\).
Therefore, no single \(L\) can satisfy the definition. The sequence does not converge.

Lila: I see! Unlike \(n\), which runs off to infinity, this one just keeps bouncing forever without settling.
Acharya Bhaskar: Precisely. These two examples : \(x_n = n\) and \(x_n = (-1)^n\), illustrate two common ways in which sequences can fail to converge.


5.4.8 Summary of Examples
In this section, we explored several examples to understand the behavior of sequences:

Some sequences converge to zero, such as \(\tfrac{1}{n}\) and \(\tfrac{1}{n^2+1}\).

Others converge to non-zero finite limits, like \(\tfrac{n}{n+1} \to 1\) and \(\tfrac{2n+3}{5n+1} \to \tfrac{2}{5}\).

Not all sequences converge:

\(\{n\}\) diverges to infinity, growing without bound.

\(\{(-1)^n\}\) oscillates, never settling to a single value.


These examples show that sequences may approach a finite limit, grow without bound, or fail to settle altogether. In each case, the precise \(\varepsilon\)–\(N\) definition helps us make these ideas rigorous.


5.4.9 Key Techniques for Proving Limits of Sequences
When proving convergence (or divergence), these strategies are especially useful:

Inequality comparison:
Show \(|x_n - L|\) is bounded above by a simpler expression that you can control.
Example: \(\tfrac{1}{n^2+1} < \tfrac{1}{n^2}\).
Algebraic simplification:
Rearrange the difference \(x_n - L\) into a form where \(n\) appears in the denominator.
Example: \(\tfrac{n}{n+1} - 1 = \tfrac{-1}{n+1}\).
Dominant term analysis:
For rational functions of \(n\), compare the highest powers of \(n\) in numerator and denominator.
Example: \(\tfrac{2n+3}{5n+1} \to \tfrac{2}{5}\).
Divergence checks:

If \(x_n \to \infty\), prove that for every \(M > 0\), eventually \(x_n > M\).
Example: \(x_n = n\).

If \(x_n\) oscillates between two or more values that stay apart, it has no limit.
Example: \(x_n = (-1)^n\).


These techniques will reappear often and form the backbone of rigorous \(\varepsilon\)–\(N\) proofs.


5.4.10 Motivation for the Comparison Theorem
Lila: In all these examples, we always end up bounding \(|x_n - L|\) by something simpler that goes to zero.
Like for \(\tfrac{1}{n^2+1}\), we said it was less than \(\tfrac{1}{n^2}\), and since that goes to zero, the sequence also goes to zero.
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. You’ve spotted a very general pattern.
If we can show that the error term \(|x_n - x|\) is not bigger than some controlling sequence that shrinks to zero, then \(x_n\) must also converge to \(x\).
Lila: So instead of always doing the \(\varepsilon\)–\(N\) argument from scratch, we can reduce it to something we already know?
Acharya Bhaskar: Yes. That’s the beauty of it.
We use one sequence \((a_n)\) that’s already known to converge to \(0\), and if \(|x_n - x|\) is squeezed under a constant multiple of \(a_n\), then \(x_n\) must converge to \(x\).
Lila: Ah, so this is like a systematic version of the trick we’ve been using.
Acharya Bhaskar: Precisely. Let me now state this as a theorem.



5.4.11 Theorem: Controlling a Sequence by Another
Theorem.
Let \((x_n)\) be a sequence of real numbers and let \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).
Suppose \((a_n)\) is a sequence of positive real numbers with \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = 0\).
If there exists a constant \(C > 0\) and an \(m \in \mathbb{N}\) such that
\[|x_n - x| \leq C \, a_n \quad \text{for all } n \geq m,\]
then
\[\lim_{n \to \infty} x_n = x.\]


Click to see the proof

We want to show that for every \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists \(N \in \mathbb{N}\) such that for all \(n > N\),
\[|x_n - x| < \varepsilon.\]
By assumption,
\[|x_n - x| \leq C a_n \quad \text{for all } n \geq m.\]
Since \(\lim_{n \to \infty} a_n = 0\), given \(\varepsilon > 0\) we know there exists \(N_1 \in \mathbb{N}\) such that for all \(n > N_1\),
\[a_n < \frac{\varepsilon}{C}.\]
So, for \(n > \max\{m, N_1\}\), we have
\[|x_n - x| \leq C a_n < C \cdot \frac{\varepsilon}{C} = \varepsilon.\]
Therefore, \(\lim_{n \to \infty} x_n = x.\)



5.4.12 Example: Using the Comparison Theorem
Lila: Can we use this theorem on an example we already know, like \(\tfrac{n}{n+1} \to 1\)?
Acharya Bhaskar: Excellent idea. Let’s try.
We want to prove
\[\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n}{n+1} = 1.\]
First compute the error:
\[\Bigg|\frac{n}{n+1} - 1\Bigg| = \frac{1}{n+1}.\]
Now notice that
\[\frac{1}{n+1} \leq \frac{1}{n} \quad \text{for all } n \geq 1.\]
So we can set \(a_n = \tfrac{1}{n}\), which we already know tends to \(0\), and take \(C = 1\).
Then the condition of the theorem is satisfied:
\[\Bigg|\frac{n}{n+1} - 1\Bigg| \leq 1 \cdot a_n.\]
By the theorem,
\[\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{n}{n+1} = 1.\]

Lila: Wow, that was much quicker than the direct \(\varepsilon\)–\(N\) proof we did earlier.
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. This theorem saves us effort. Once you have a few standard sequences like \(\tfrac{1}{n}\) or \(\tfrac{1}{n^2}\) whose limits you know, you can use them as benchmarks to prove many others.


5.4.13 Example: A Rational Limit with the Comparison Theorem
Lila: Can we also use the theorem for something that looks a bit more complicated, like
\[x_n = \frac{2n+3}{5n+1}?\]
Acharya Bhaskar: Certainly. We already proved directly that
\[\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2n+3}{5n+1} = \frac{2}{5}.\]
Let’s see how the comparison theorem helps.
First, compute the error:
\[
\frac{2n+3}{5n+1} - \frac{2}{5} = \frac{13}{25n+5}.
\]
So,
\[\Bigg|\frac{2n+3}{5n+1} - \frac{2}{5}\Bigg| = \frac{13}{25n+5}.\]
Now notice that for all \(n \geq 1\),
\[\frac{13}{25n+5} \leq \frac{13}{25n} = \frac{13}{25}\cdot \frac{1}{n}.\]
So we can set \(a_n = \tfrac{1}{n}\) (which goes to \(0\)) and \(C = \tfrac{13}{25}\).
Then
\[|x_n - \tfrac{2}{5}| \leq C \, a_n.\]
By the theorem,
\[\lim_{n \to \infty} \frac{2n+3}{5n+1} = \frac{2}{5}.\]

Lila: That really simplifies things! Instead of wrestling with inequalities, we just compare to \(\tfrac{1}{n}\).
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. This method is especially powerful for rational sequences, where the error often turns into a constant times \(\tfrac{1}{n}\).


5.4.14 Example: Proving \(\lim_{n \to \infty} c^{1/n} = 1\) using Bernoulli’s Inequality
Lila: I remember you said that \(\lim c^{1/n} = 1\) for \(c > 0\). Can we prove this?

5.4.14.1 Bernoulli’s Inequality
Acharya Bhaskar: Before we use it in our proofs, let me remind you of an important inequality.
Bernoulli’s Inequality.
For any real number \(t \geq -1\) and any natural number \(n\),
\[(1+t)^n \geq 1 + n t.\]

Lila: That looks simple, but why is it true?
Acharya Bhaskar: Let’s prove it by induction.


Click to see the proof

Base case (\(n=1\)):
\[(1+t)^1 = 1+t = 1+1\cdot t,\]
so the inequality is true.

Inductive step:
Assume \((1+t)^n \geq 1 + n t\) holds for some \(n \in \mathbb{N}\).
Then
\[(1+t)^{n+1} = (1+t)^n (1+t).\]
By the induction hypothesis,
\[(1+t)^{n+1} \geq (1+nt)(1+t).\]
Expanding,
\[(1+nt)(1+t) = 1 + (n+1)t + n t^2.\]
Since \(t^2 \geq 0\),
\[(1+nt)(1+t) \geq 1 + (n+1)t.\]
Therefore,
\[(1+t)^{n+1} \geq 1 + (n+1)t.\]
This completes the induction.

Thus, for all \(t \geq -1\) and all \(n \in \mathbb{N}\),
\[(1+t)^n \geq 1 + n t.\] ✅

Lila: So the inequality is really just saying that the binomial expansion always produces extra positive terms after \(1 + nt\).
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. And as we’ll see, it’s very handy in bounding expressions like \((1+\varepsilon)^n\) in convergence proofs. Now, we can prove the main result \(\lim_{n \to \infty} c^{1/n} = 1\)



Click to see the proof

We want to prove: for every \(\varepsilon > 0\), there exists \(N\) such that for \(n > N\),
\[|c^{1/n} - 1| < \varepsilon.\]

Case 1: \(c > 1\).
Let \(\varepsilon > 0\). Consider \(1+\varepsilon > 1\).
Then
\[(1+\varepsilon)^n \geq 1 + n\varepsilon \quad \text{(by Bernoulli’s inequality)}.\]
So \((1+\varepsilon)^n\) grows without bound as \(n \to \infty\).
Therefore, for sufficiently large \(n\), we must have
\[(1+\varepsilon)^n > c.\]
That means
\[c^{1/n} < 1 + \varepsilon.\]
On the other hand, since \(c > 1\), clearly \(c^{1/n} > 1\) for all \(n\).
So for large \(n\):
\[1 < c^{1/n} < 1 + \varepsilon \quad \implies \quad |c^{1/n} - 1| < \varepsilon.\]

Case 2: \(0 < c < 1\).
Write \(c = \tfrac{1}{d}\) where \(d > 1\). Then
\[c^{1/n} = \frac{1}{d^{1/n}}.\]
From Case 1, \(d^{1/n} \to 1\), so \(\tfrac{1}{d^{1/n}} \to 1\) as well.

Case 3: \(c = 1\).
Trivial, since \(c^{1/n} = 1\) for all \(n\).

Thus, in all cases \(c^{1/n} \to 1\) as \(n \to \infty\). ✅

Lila: Oh! So Bernoulli’s inequality was the key — it gave us a bound that forced \(c^{1/n}\) close to \(1\).
Acharya Bhaskar: Exactly. This is a nice example of how inequalities can give very clean convergence proofs.
